content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that more than 4,000,000 men and women from the United States served in World War I, with 2,000,000 serving overseas and 375,000 casualties. The events of 1914-1918 had a significant impact on the world and the country, and the centennial of the war provides an opportunity for Americans to learn about their predecessors' sacrifices. commemorative efforts help gain historical understanding of past conflicts. Kansas City is home to America's National World War I Museum, which seeks to preserve the history of World War I and educate people about its significant consequences. Missouri is the home state of General John Joseph Pershing, who commanded the American Expeditionary Forces in Europe during World War I. Kansas City also houses the national headquarters for the Veterans of Foreign Wars. The Kansas City area is home to the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library and Museum, as well as the Dwight David Eisenhower Presidential Library and Museum located in the neighboring State of Kansas. The Act establishes a commission in Kansas City, Missouri, to commemorate the centennial of World War I by promoting values of honor, courage, patriotism, and sacrifice. The World War I Centennial Commission is established to plan, develop, and execute programs to commemorate the centennial of World War I. It encourages participation from private organizations and governments, facilitates activities nationwide, and serves as a clearinghouse for information. The Commission consists of 24 members appointed to carry out these duties. The World War I Centennial Commission consists of 24 members appointed by various leaders and the President, as well as representatives from veterans' organizations. The World War I Centennial Commission consists of 24 members appointed by various leaders and the President, as well as representatives from veterans' organizations. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members serve without pay. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members serve without pay. Each member receives travel expenses and per diem, a quorum is set at thirteen members, the Commission elects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson, and meetings are called by the Chairperson with the first meeting held at America's National World War I Museum. The World War I Centennial Commission appoints an executive director and additional personnel to perform duties, with the executive director's pay not exceeding the rate of basic pay for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Executive Schedule sets pay for the executive director and additional personnel appointed by the World War I Centennial Commission. The executive director can determine the pay for additional personnel. They are required to work at the building housing America's National World War I Museum in Kansas City, Missouri. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants as needed. The Commission, under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, can request temporary services from federal agencies. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission is authorized to obtain official data from US departments or agencies and accept gifts, bequests, or devises to aid its work. The Commission may use the United States mails and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. They are authorized to procure supplies, services, and property for their responsibilities under this Act. The Commission is authorized to procure supplies, services, and property, and make contracts, leases, or legal agreements, with a limitation on the duration of such agreements. They are required to submit periodic reports to Congress and the President on their activities and plans, as well as specific recommendations for commemorating the centennial of World War I. The Commission authorized to procure supplies, services, and property, make contracts, and submit reports to Congress. The Commission will terminate after activities honoring World War I centennial or by July 28, 2019. The Act will be effective on January 1, 2010.
